articles.title: Councils to get £3bn for thousands more school spaces for Send pupils
articles.summary: The government is promising 50,000 more places for children with special educational needs in schools in England.
articles.content:
Councils to get £3bn for thousands more school spaces for Send pupils

6 hours ago Share Save Vanessa Clarke Education reporter Share Save

Getty Images

The government has promised to create 50,000 more places for children with special educational needs (Send) in mainstream schools in England. It plans to invest £3bn over the next three years, partly funded by cancelling the building of some planned free schools. Councils - who will receive the funding - have argued the money needs to be diverted to the right areas and to the people who know what is needed in their local communities. Nearly 1.7 million pupils receive support for special educational needs in schools in England, with the number rising every year.

Education Secretary Bridget Phillipson said the investment would lay the groundwork for the Send reforms announced in the schools White Paper early next year. The White Paper had been due to be published in the autumn, but was delayed. The government says it plans to cancel the building of 28 new mainstream free schools following a consultation and that it is reviewing a further 16 sites. "We have made the decision not to go ahead with some schools where we've seen falling rolls because of pupil numbers and investing that money into provision for children with Send", Ms Phillipson told the BBC. Councils will be able to use the money from the cancelled projects to adapt existing school buildings and create more specialist spaces, so pupils are less likely to have to travel far for their education. For example, they could create areas like breakout spaces for children who may need more support, or rooms to support children with autism or ADHD who may feel overstimulated in the classroom. There are also 77 proposed special free schools which local authorities can decide to build, or similarly, use the funding to create the equivalent number of specialist places elsewhere. Councillor Amanda Hopgood from the Local Government Association says the Send places needed to be in the right location. "If we build a big school in the middle of nowhere that we have to transport everyone to, then that's money that isn't used on education". "And those children are not being educated in their local communities where they live with their friends". Local authorities spent £1.5bn on transport for under-16s with Send in the 2023-24 financial year, about two-and-a-half times what it was in 2015-16.

Headteachers' unions have welcomed the plans. However, the school leaders' union NAHT says investment in buildings is only one part of the picture, and that there would need to be sufficient teachers and leaders "with the right level of specialist training". At Ninestiles, an academy in Birmingham, just under 50 students with an education, health and care plan (EHCP) - a legal document outlining the support that a young person is entitled to - spend around 70% of their time in mainstream lessons. The rest of the time, they take part in bespoke lessons to support their needs, where they get access to specially-trained staff and a tailored curriculum. Demand for these places is high and the government says the extra investment means councils would be able to meet local need faster. But Principal Alex Hughes says "the devil will be in the detail" and in "what it translates to" for individual schools. Student Brendan, 14, who attends Ninestiles has access to the full curriculum but also can attend the resource hub, where he is supported by teachers. He has the "best of both worlds", according to his mum Laura Jerram who says the pastoral support he has received has been "the key to keeping him in the school". But Brendan's journey to get to this point has been "really difficult". He missed a lot of primary school before he came to Ninestiles and the process of getting an EHCP was "a horrible journey", Ms Jerram explains. "It's a bit of a bun fight [to get an EHCP] and the most resourced families tend to come out on top, unfortunately. "I feel that for Brendan, if he'd had support much earlier on, he may not have fallen out of education the way he did."

Gemma Laister/BBC Mum Laura Jerram says trying to get an EHCP for her son was a horrible journey and families need help much earlier on

articles.personality_title: England invests £3bn to create 50,000 new school places for children with special needs
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In England, nearly 1.7 million children receive support for special educational needs (SEND) in schools. The number of these pupils is increasing every year, and there is a growing need for more suitable school places and support.

**What happened** – The government announced a £3 billion investment over the next three years to create 50,000 new school places for children with SEND. This money will come partly from cancelling the construction of some planned new free schools. Local councils will get the funding to improve existing schools by adding specialist spaces like quiet rooms or areas designed for children with autism or ADHD. The goal is to provide more places closer to where children live, so they don’t have to travel far.

**Impact** – This is important because it helps children with special needs learn in their local communities, with better support and less travel. Councils can decide how best to use the money, which means the changes can fit local needs. Currently, councils spend a lot on transporting children to distant schools, so this investment could reduce that cost and improve children’s school experience. Headteachers welcome the funding but say schools also need well-trained staff to support these students.

**What's next step** – The government will continue working with councils to build or improve specialist places. There are plans for 77 new special free schools, but councils can also use the money to improve other local schools. The government will also release a White Paper with more SEND reforms next year. Families and schools will watch closely to see how the funding helps children in practice.

**One-sentence takeaway** – England is investing £3 billion to create thousands more local school places for children with special educational needs, aiming to improve support and reduce travel for these students.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’Angleterre investit 3 milliards de livres pour créer 50 000 nouvelles places scolaires pour les enfants en situation de handicap
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En Angleterre, près de 1,7 million d’enfants bénéficient d’un accompagnement pour des besoins éducatifs particuliers (SEND). Ce nombre augmente chaque année, ce qui crée un besoin croissant de places scolaires adaptées.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le gouvernement a annoncé un investissement de 3 milliards de livres sur trois ans pour créer 50 000 nouvelles places scolaires pour les enfants avec SEND. Cet argent provient en partie de l’annulation de la construction de certaines nouvelles écoles gratuites prévues. Les conseils locaux recevront les fonds pour améliorer les écoles existantes en ajoutant des espaces spécialisés, comme des salles calmes ou des zones pour les enfants autistes ou atteints de TDAH. L’objectif est de proposer plus de places près du domicile des enfants, pour éviter les longs trajets.

**Impact** – Cela est important car cela permet aux enfants en situation de handicap d’apprendre dans leur communauté locale, avec un meilleur soutien et moins de déplacements. Les conseils locaux peuvent choisir comment utiliser l’argent selon leurs besoins, ce qui rend les changements plus adaptés. Actuellement, beaucoup d’argent est dépensé pour transporter ces enfants vers des écoles éloignées. Ce financement pourrait réduire ces coûts et améliorer l’expérience scolaire. Les directeurs d’école accueillent favorablement ces fonds, mais soulignent aussi le besoin d’avoir des enseignants bien formés.

**Prochaine étape** – Le gouvernement continuera de travailler avec les conseils locaux pour construire ou améliorer les places spécialisées. Il y a 77 nouvelles écoles gratuites spécialisées prévues, mais les conseils peuvent aussi utiliser l’argent pour améliorer d’autres écoles locales. Un Livre blanc avec d’autres réformes SEND est attendu l’année prochaine. Les familles et les écoles surveilleront de près l’impact réel de ce financement.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’Angleterre investit 3 milliards de livres pour créer des milliers de places scolaires locales pour les enfants avec des besoins éducatifs particuliers, afin d’améliorer leur soutien et réduire leurs déplacements.
articles.personality_title_es: Inglaterra invierte £3 mil millones para crear 50,000 nuevas plazas escolares para niños con necesidades especiales

**Qué pasó** – El gobierno anunció una inversión de £3 mil millones durante los próximos tres años para crear 50,000 nuevas plazas escolares para niños con SEND. Parte del dinero proviene de cancelar la construcción de algunas escuelas gratuitas planificadas. Los consejos locales recibirán los fondos para mejorar las escuelas existentes añadiendo espacios especializados, como salas tranquilas o áreas para niños con autismo o TDAH. El objetivo es ofrecer más plazas cerca de donde viven los niños, para que no tengan que viajar lejos.

**Impacto** – Esto es importante porque ayuda a que los niños con necesidades especiales estudien en sus comunidades locales, con mejor apoyo y menos desplazamientos. Los consejos pueden decidir cómo usar el dinero según las necesidades locales, haciendo los cambios más adecuados. articles.title: Press release - European Parliament election campaign rewarded for creative innovation
articles.summary: The European Parliament’s communication campaign for the 2024 European elections has been recognised with a series of major creative industry awards. Source : © European Union, 2025 - EP
articles.content:
The communication campaign for Parliament’s 2024 elections, “Pass It On – Use Your Vote”, created in cooperation with NoA | &Co. and ICF Next, has been honoured with numerous international, European, and national awards.

Its most prominent distinction came earlier this month with the Eurobest Creative Effectiveness Grand Prix, which recognised the campaign’s strong concept, cross-European relevance, and tangible impact on democratic engagement.

Earlier, the campaign received top national recognition at Denmark’s The True Award (for film direction, a film over 60 seconds, and casting), and the Jury’s Coup de Cœur at L’Agence Média de l’Année (brand content/CSR). It went on to secure two gold awards at the Danish Digital Awards (use of content, purpose/NGO + public) and multiple international accolades including bronze at the Clio Awards (unscripted film, creative effectiveness), a One Show Gold Pencil (casting), and a D&AD Wood Pencil (casting).

Further major distinctions included a gold at La Nuit des Rois (corporate & institutional), a gold Deauville Green Award (human rights), gold at the Creative Circle Awards Denmark (earned media), wins at the Danish Rambuk Awards (campaign, effect), and three Silver Effies from Effie Denmark (branded content, non-profit, public relations). The campaign was also shortlisted at the 2025 Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity.

Implemented across all 27 EU Member States, the campaign achieved remarkable visibility and engagement: 40% recall, 339 million completed online views, 1.06 billion impressions, and a significant increase in turnout among those who remembered the campaign — contributing to the highest participation in a European election since 1994.

At its centre was a four-minute documentary featuring grandparents and grandchildren from every EU country, whose unscripted conversations on freedom, choices, and democratic responsibility offered a personal and relatable entry point into Europe’s shared democratic values.

Christian Mangold, Director-general for Communication at the European Parliament, welcomed the prizes: “This recognition underlines the power of connecting with people through stories drawn from real experience. ‘Pass It On’ reminded Europeans that democracy has to be protected together and handed down from one generation to the next. When citizens see their own lives reflected in these stories, they are more inclined to see the value of democracy.”

The campaign was delivered through a fully integrated mix of paid, earned, shared, and owned media. It achieved unprecedented levels of organic coverage, including a screening at the Cannes Film Festival and showings in almost 900 cinemas across Europe.

Key figures
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a highly successful and impactful European Parliament election campaign that significantly boosted democratic engagement across all 27 EU member states, leading to the highest voter turnout since 1994. The campaign’s focus on democracy, freedom, and civic responsibility has broad societal significance and real-world positive impact on democratic participation, supported by detailed context and measurable outcomes.

The campaign featured a four-minute documentary showing real conversations between grandparents and grandchildren from every EU country, talking about freedom and democracy.

articles.title: Japan: Promote Safe Sports by Ending Abuse, Discrimination
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Junichi Kawai, the commissioner of the Japan Sports Agency, delivers a speech in Nagoya, Japan, October 18, 2025.
                    © 2025 The Yomiuri Shimbun via AP Photo 
          
    


  
(Tokyo) – The Japanese government’s Japan Sports Agency (JSA) should adopt policies to promote safe sports in Japan by ending abuses and discrimination against athletes, 12 nongovernmental organizations and individuals said in a joint letter to Junichi Kawai, the JSA’s commissioner. Kawai, the former chairman of the Japanese Paralympic Committee, was appointed commissioner effective October 1, 2025.On November 28, the signers urged the JSA to prioritize safety in sports, calling it a critical step to protect athletes from all forms of abuse. The signers include, Athlete Save Japan, Human Rights Watch, Japan Safe Sport Project, Kantokuga Okottewa Ikenai Taikai, Sport for Creating Pathways Japan (S.C.P. Japan), Unisocc, and five athletes and experts.“Abuse against athletes, including children, has been normalized in sports in Japan,” said Hanna Yumura, Asia officer at Human Rights Watch. “We are encouraged to see some progress but expect the JSA to take further action to adopt international standards and effective safe sport policies to protect all athletes.”Human Rights Watch’s 2020 report, “‘I Was Hit So Many Times I Can’t Count: Abuse of Child Athletes in Japan,” documents the use of corporal punishment and systemic child abuse in sports training from grassroots to school to elite sports. The following year, as part of #AthletesAgainstAbuse, an international campaign to stop abuse in sports, six leading athletic and human rights organizations wrote to the JSA calling for the government to establish a Japan Center for Safe Sport.A safe sport center would be an independent body tasked with addressing abuse in sport. Such a center would allow athletes, parents and children to report abuse in an environment that protects against retaliation. It would also enable the authorities to track how the reports are handled to ensure the effectiveness of the complaint mechanism.The government should also pass a Safe Sport Act under articles 8 and 29(1) of the Basic Act on Sport, the organizations said. Such legislation would provide the legal basis for establishing the Japan Center for Safe Sport. It could also serve as a tool to prohibit all forms of abuse in sports by, for example, obligating sport organizations to respond to cases appropriately.“A safe sport center and a Safe Sport Act will strengthen the protection of athletes in Japan from all forms of abuse and discrimination,” said Shoichi Sugiyama, a lawyer for athletes’ rights and founder of the Japan Safe Sport Project. “These institutions would enhance inclusiveness in sports, including welcoming those with disabilities and LGBTQ+ athletes.”“This is a critical time,” said Katsumi Mori, professor at the Faculty of Sports Humanities and Applied Social Science of the National Institute of Fitness and Sports in Kanoya. “In June, Japan revised the Basic Act on Sport, requiring the national government to adopt measures against abuse, and this can serve as a basis for introducing a Safe Sport Act in Japan.”The Japanese government should also address beating athletes in sports training and other kinds of abuse in sport that can cause lifelong trauma for children and older athletes, the organizations said.“Every time a child steps on the field, they should feel safe and never have to worry about abuse or discrimination,” said Yuiko Inoue, a former soccer player and the representative director of S.C.P. Japan. “The Japanese government has made efforts in this direction, but it is vital for this message to reach athletes, coaches, parents and officials across Japan: whether in school sports or elite sports.”

Click to expand Image Junichi Kawai, the commissioner of the Japan Sports Agency, delivers a speech in Nagoya, Japan, October 18, 2025. © 2025 The Yomiuri Shimbun via AP Photo

(Tokyo) – The Japanese government’s Japan Sports Agency (JSA) should adopt policies to promote safe sports in Japan by ending abuses and discrimination against athletes, 12 nongovernmental organizations and individuals said in a joint letter to Junichi Kawai, the JSA’s commissioner. Kawai, the former chairman of the Japanese Paralympic Committee, was appointed commissioner effective October 1, 2025.

On November 28, the signers urged the JSA to prioritize safety in sports, calling it a critical step to protect athletes from all forms of abuse. The signers include, Athlete Save Japan, Human Rights Watch, Japan Safe Sport Project, Kantokuga Okottewa Ikenai Taikai, Sport for Creating Pathways Japan (S.C.P. Japan), Unisocc, and five athletes and experts.

“Abuse against athletes, including children, has been normalized in sports in Japan,” said Hanna Yumura, Asia officer at Human Rights Watch. “We are encouraged to see some progress but expect the JSA to take further action to adopt international standards and effective safe sport policies to protect all athletes.”

Human Rights Watch’s 2020 report, “‘I Was Hit So Many Times I Can’t Count: Abuse of Child Athletes in Japan,” documents the use of corporal punishment and systemic child abuse in sports training from grassroots to school to elite sports. The following year, as part of #AthletesAgainstAbuse, an international campaign to stop abuse in sports, six leading athletic and human rights organizations wrote to the JSA calling for the government to establish a Japan Center for Safe Sport.

A safe sport center would be an independent body tasked with addressing abuse in sport. Such a center would allow athletes, parents and children to report abuse in an environment that protects against retaliation. It would also enable the authorities to track how the reports are handled to ensure the effectiveness of the complaint mechanism.

The government should also pass a Safe Sport Act under articles 8 and 29(1) of the Basic Act on Sport, the organizations said. Such legislation would provide the legal basis for establishing the Japan Center for Safe Sport. It could also serve as a tool to prohibit all forms of abuse in sports by, for example, obligating sport organizations to respond to cases appropriately.

“A safe sport center and a Safe Sport Act will strengthen the protection of athletes in Japan from all forms of abuse and discrimination,” said Shoichi Sugiyama, a lawyer for athletes’ rights and founder of the Japan Safe Sport Project. “These institutions would enhance inclusiveness in sports, including welcoming those with disabilities and LGBTQ+ athletes.”

“This is a critical time,” said Katsumi Mori, professor at the Faculty of Sports Humanities and Applied Social Science of the National Institute of Fitness and Sports in Kanoya. “In June, Japan revised the Basic Act on Sport, requiring the national government to adopt measures against abuse, and this can serve as a basis for introducing a Safe Sport Act in Japan.”

The Japanese government should also address beating athletes in sports training and other kinds of abuse in sport that can cause lifelong trauma for children and older athletes, the organizations said.

“Every time a child steps on the field, they should feel safe and never have to worry about abuse or discrimination,” said Yuiko Inoue, a former soccer player and the representative director of S.C.P. Japan. “The Japanese government has made efforts in this direction, but it is vital for this message to reach athletes, coaches, parents and officials across Japan: whether in school sports or elite sports.”

This has broad societal impact by promoting safe and inclusive sports environments for children and adults, including marginalized groups. The story is focused, detailed, and addresses a critical human rights issue with tangible policy proposals.
articles.personality_title: Japan moves to protect athletes by ending abuse and discrimination in sports
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In Japan, abuse and discrimination against athletes, including children, have been common problems in sports. Human rights groups and sports organizations have been calling for stronger protections to make sports safer for everyone.

**What happened** – On November 28, twelve organizations and experts sent a joint letter to Junichi Kawai, the new commissioner of the Japan Sports Agency (JSA), asking him to create safer sports environments. They want the government to set up a Japan Center for Safe Sport, an independent place where athletes can report abuse without fear. They also urge passing a Safe Sport Act to legally stop all kinds of abuse and discrimination in sports.

**Impact** – This is important because it recognizes that abuse in sports training has been a serious issue in Japan, affecting children and adults alike. Creating a safe sport center and law would help protect athletes from harm and make sports more welcoming, including for people with disabilities and LGBTQ+ athletes. It would ensure reports of abuse are properly handled and that sports groups must respond to problems.

**What's next step** – Japan recently updated its Basic Act on Sport to require action against abuse. Now, the government is expected to introduce the Safe Sport Act and establish the safe sport center. These steps will help create clearer rules and support systems for athletes, coaches, and families across Japan.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Japan is taking concrete steps to stop abuse and discrimination in sports by proposing new laws and a safe reporting center to protect all athletes.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Japon agit pour protéger les athlètes en mettant fin aux abus et à la discrimination dans le sport
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Au Japon, les abus et la discrimination contre les athlètes, y compris les enfants, sont des problèmes fréquents dans le sport. Des groupes de défense des droits humains et des organisations sportives demandent des protections plus fortes pour rendre le sport plus sûr.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le 28 novembre, douze organisations et experts ont envoyé une lettre commune à Junichi Kawai, le nouveau commissaire de l'Agence japonaise du sport (JSA), pour lui demander de créer un environnement sportif plus sûr. Ils souhaitent que le gouvernement mette en place un Centre japonais pour le sport sûr, un lieu indépendant où les athlètes peuvent signaler les abus sans crainte. Ils demandent aussi l'adoption d'une loi sur le sport sûr pour interdire légalement tous les types d'abus et de discrimination dans le sport.

**Impact** – Cela est important car cela reconnaît que les abus dans l'entraînement sportif sont un problème grave au Japon, touchant enfants et adultes. La création d'un centre sûr et d'une loi aidera à protéger les athlètes et à rendre le sport plus inclusif, notamment pour les personnes handicapées et LGBTQ+. Cela garantira que les signalements d'abus soient bien traités et que les organisations sportives réagissent aux problèmes.

**Étapes suivantes** – Le Japon a récemment révisé sa loi de base sur le sport pour exiger des mesures contre les abus. Le gouvernement devrait maintenant introduire la loi sur le sport sûr et établir ce centre. Ces mesures aideront à créer des règles claires et des systèmes de soutien pour les athlètes, entraîneurs et familles partout au Japon.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Le Japon prend des mesures concrètes pour arrêter les abus et la discrimination dans le sport en proposant de nouvelles lois et un centre de signalement sûr pour protéger tous les athlètes.
articles.personality_title_es: Japón avanza para proteger a los atletas y acabar con el abuso y la discriminación en el deporte
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En Japón, el abuso y la discriminación contra los atletas, incluidos los niños, han sido problemas comunes en el deporte. Grupos de derechos humanos y organizaciones deportivas han pedido protecciones más fuertes para que el deporte sea más seguro para todos.

**Qué pasó** – El 28 de noviembre, doce organizaciones y expertos enviaron una carta conjunta a Junichi Kawai, el nuevo comisionado de la Agencia Deportiva de Japón (JSA), pidiéndole que cree ambientes deportivos más seguros. Quieren que el gobierno establezca un Centro Japonés de Deporte Seguro, un lugar independiente donde los atletas puedan denunciar abusos sin miedo. También solicitan aprobar una Ley de Deporte Seguro para prohibir legalmente todo tipo de abuso y discriminación en el deporte.

**Impacto** – Esto es importante porque reconoce que el abuso en el entrenamiento deportivo ha sido un problema serio en Japón, afectando a niños y adultos. Crear un centro de deporte seguro y una ley ayudará a proteger a los atletas y a hacer el deporte más inclusivo, incluso para personas con discapacidades y atletas LGBTQ+. Asegurará que los reportes de abuso se manejen correctamente y que las organizaciones deportivas respondan a los problemas.

**Próximos pasos** – Japón actualizó recientemente su Ley Básica del Deporte para exigir acciones contra el abuso. Ahora se espera que el gobierno presente la Ley de Deporte Seguro y establezca el centro seguro. Estos pasos ayudarán a crear reglas claras y sistemas de apoyo para atletas, entrenadores y familias en todo Japón.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Japón está tomando medidas concretas para detener el abuso y la discriminación en el deporte mediante nuevas leyes y un centro seguro para proteger a todos los atletas.

articles.title: Tulsa Ancestor’s Legacy Underscores Lasting Fight for Reparations
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Queen Mother and Founder of the VFF Foundation, Viola Ford Fletcher, at the Oldest Living Tulsa Oklahoma Massacre Survivors Celebrated And Book Cover Revealing at The City Club of Washington in Washington, DC, US, February 28, 2023.
                    © 2023 Brian Stukes/Getty Images
          
    


  
The recent passing of Queen Mother Viola Ford Fletcher, at age 111, marked a profound loss in the ongoing fight for justice for survivors of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre, the racist attack that left hundreds of Black people dead and more than 1,200 Black-owned houses burned to the ground. As the oldest known living survivor, she embodied the resilience of the Greenwood district, once known as “Black Wall Street.”Queen Mother Fletcher’s tireless advocacy, which included testifying before the US Congress on the massacre’s centennial, underscores the profound importance of reparations. For survivors and their descendants, reparations are not merely about compensation. They are a necessary step toward accountability and the repair of systemic failures.International human rights law mandates full and effective reparations for the victims of gross violations of human rights. Just as important, the United States’ human rights obligations require it to repair the ongoing, intergenerational harm caused by the massacre. The survivors of the Tulsa Race Massacre and their descendants’ pursuit of reparations is a fight to compel the US to uphold its moral and legal obligation to repair that lasting damage, including the lost generational wealth, ongoing psychological trauma, and continuing socioeconomic disparities for Black people in the US.The legal fight for massacre reparations faced a major setback when the Oklahoma Supreme Court dismissed the survivors’ lawsuit in June 2024, ruling that the century-old harm did not constitute a current public nuisance. Following this, the Department of Justice released a review under the Emmett Till Act that officially acknowledged the massacre as a coordinated, military-style attack, though it found no avenue for criminal prosecution over a century later.The call for justice was echoed by leaders like Congresswoman Ayanna Pressley, who, upon Queen Mother Fletcher’s passing, honored her on the House floor, stating that “her legacy is a call to continue the fight for full reparations.” The congresswoman, who reintroduced H.R. 40 earlier this year to begin the path toward reparations, demanded that the United States “honor her transition to Ancestor by moving in her spirit with unyielding hope, moral clarity, and faith that justice, though delayed, is not denied.” Queen Mother Fletcher’s legacy is a call to action and a demand for the US to fulfill its obligation to remedy injustice and provide tangible redress for the foundational violence against Black people.
articles.content:
Click to expand Image Queen Mother and Founder of the VFF Foundation, Viola Ford Fletcher, at the Oldest Living Tulsa Oklahoma Massacre Survivors Celebrated And Book Cover Revealing at The City Club of Washington in Washington, DC, US, February 28, 2023. © 2023 Brian Stukes/Getty Images

The recent passing of Queen Mother Viola Ford Fletcher, at age 111, marked a profound loss in the ongoing fight for justice for survivors of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre, the racist attack that left hundreds of Black people dead and more than 1,200 Black-owned houses burned to the ground. As the oldest known living survivor, she embodied the resilience of the Greenwood district, once known as “Black Wall Street.”

Queen Mother Fletcher’s tireless advocacy, which included testifying before the US Congress on the massacre’s centennial, underscores the profound importance of reparations. For survivors and their descendants, reparations are not merely about compensation. They are a necessary step toward accountability and the repair of systemic failures.

International human rights law mandates full and effective reparations for the victims of gross violations of human rights. Just as important, the United States’ human rights obligations require it to repair the ongoing, intergenerational harm caused by the massacre. The survivors of the Tulsa Race Massacre and their descendants’ pursuit of reparations is a fight to compel the US to uphold its moral and legal obligation to repair that lasting damage, including the lost generational wealth, ongoing psychological trauma, and continuing socioeconomic disparities for Black people in the US.

The legal fight for massacre reparations faced a major setback when the Oklahoma Supreme Court dismissed the survivors’ lawsuit in June 2024, ruling that the century-old harm did not constitute a current public nuisance. Following this, the Department of Justice released a review under the Emmett Till Act that officially acknowledged the massacre as a coordinated, military-style attack, though it found no avenue for criminal prosecution over a century later.

The call for justice was echoed by leaders like Congresswoman Ayanna Pressley, who, upon Queen Mother Fletcher’s passing, honored her on the House floor, stating that “her legacy is a call to continue the fight for full reparations.” The congresswoman, who reintroduced H.R. 40 earlier this year to begin the path toward reparations, demanded that the United States “honor her transition to Ancestor by moving in her spirit with unyielding hope, moral clarity, and faith that justice, though delayed, is not denied.” Queen Mother Fletcher’s legacy is a call to action and a demand for the US to fulfill its obligation to remedy injustice and provide tangible redress for the foundational violence against Black people.

articles.personality_title: Queen Mother Viola Ford Fletcher’s legacy strengthens the fight for Tulsa Massacre reparations
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In 1921, a violent attack known as the Tulsa Race Massacre destroyed a thriving Black community in Tulsa, Oklahoma, killing hundreds and burning over 1,200 Black-owned homes. Survivors and their families have sought reparations, or compensation, for the lasting harm caused by this event.

**What happened** – Queen Mother Viola Ford Fletcher, the oldest known survivor of the massacre, passed away at 111 years old. She spent much of her life speaking out for justice and reparations, even testifying before the US Congress on the massacre’s 100th anniversary. Despite a recent court ruling rejecting a lawsuit for reparations, government officials officially recognized the massacre as a planned military-style attack.

**Impact** – Fletcher’s work highlighted that reparations are not just payments but a needed step to fix the harm caused by the massacre, including lost family wealth and ongoing trauma. Her story shows how survivors continue to demand the US government take responsibility and follow human rights laws that call for making things right after serious injustices.

**What’s next step** – Leaders like Congresswoman Ayanna Pressley are pushing to pass H.R. 40, a bill aimed at starting reparations for Black Americans. Fletcher’s legacy inspires others to keep fighting for justice and to ensure the government honors its promises to repair the damage done by the massacre.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Viola Ford Fletcher’s life and advocacy remind us that seeking reparations for the Tulsa Race Massacre remains a vital effort to address historic and ongoing racial harm in America.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’héritage de Queen Mother Viola Ford Fletcher renforce la lutte pour les réparations du massacre de Tulsa
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En 1921, une attaque violente connue sous le nom de massacre racial de Tulsa a détruit une communauté noire prospère à Tulsa, Oklahoma, tuant des centaines de personnes et brûlant plus de 1 200 maisons appartenant à des Noirs. Les survivants et leurs familles ont demandé des réparations, c’est-à-dire une compensation, pour les dommages durables causés par cet événement.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Queen Mother Viola Ford Fletcher, la plus ancienne survivante connue du massacre, est décédée à l’âge de 111 ans. Elle a consacré une grande partie de sa vie à réclamer justice et réparations, témoignant même devant le Congrès américain lors du centenaire du massacre. Malgré un récent rejet judiciaire d’une plainte pour réparations, des responsables gouvernementaux ont officiellement reconnu le massacre comme une attaque militaire planifiée.

**Impact** – Le travail de Fletcher a montré que les réparations ne sont pas seulement des paiements, mais une étape nécessaire pour réparer les dommages causés par le massacre, y compris la richesse familiale perdue et les traumatismes persistants. Son histoire démontre comment les survivants continuent d’exiger que le gouvernement américain assume ses responsabilités et respecte les lois sur les droits humains qui demandent de réparer les injustices graves.

**Prochaine étape** – Des leaders comme la députée Ayanna Pressley poussent à faire adopter le projet de loi H.R. 40, visant à lancer les réparations pour les Afro-Américains. L’héritage de Fletcher inspire d’autres à continuer la lutte pour la justice et à s’assurer que le gouvernement honore ses promesses de réparer les dommages causés par le massacre.

**Une phrase clé** – La vie et le combat de Viola Ford Fletcher rappellent que la quête de réparations pour le massacre racial de Tulsa reste un effort essentiel pour réparer un tort historique et actuel aux États-Unis.
articles.personality_title_es: El legado de Queen Mother Viola Ford Fletcher fortalece la lucha por las reparaciones del masacre de Tulsa
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En 1921, un ataque violento conocido como la Masacre Racial de Tulsa destruyó una próspera comunidad negra en Tulsa, Oklahoma, dejando cientos de muertos y más de 1,200 casas negras quemadas. Los sobrevivientes y sus familias han buscado reparaciones, o compensación, por el daño duradero causado por este evento.

**Qué pasó** – Queen Mother Viola Ford Fletcher, la sobreviviente más longeva conocida de la masacre, falleció a los 111 años. Pasó gran parte de su vida luchando por justicia y reparaciones, incluso testificando ante el Congreso de Estados Unidos en el centenario de la masacre. A pesar de un fallo judicial reciente que rechazó una demanda por reparaciones, funcionarios oficiales reconocieron la masacre como un ataque militar planeado.

**Impacto** – El trabajo de Fletcher destacó que las reparaciones no son solo pagos, sino un paso necesario para reparar el daño causado por la masacre, incluyendo la pérdida de riqueza familiar y el trauma continuo. Su historia muestra cómo los sobrevivientes siguen exigiendo que el gobierno de EE. UU. asuma la responsabilidad y cumpla con las leyes de derechos humanos que exigen reparar injusticias graves.

**Próximo paso** – Líderes como la congresista Ayanna Pressley están impulsando la aprobación del proyecto de ley H.R. 40, que busca iniciar reparaciones para los afroamericanos. El legado de Fletcher inspira a otros a continuar la lucha por la justicia y a asegurar que el gobierno cumpla sus promesas de reparar los daños causados por la masacre.

**Una frase clave** – La vida y defensa de Viola Ford Fletcher recuerdan que la búsqueda de reparaciones por la Masacre Racial de Tulsa sigue siendo un esfuerzo vital para enfrentar el daño racial histórico y actual en Estados Unidos.
